awd_titl_txt: Ionic and Molecular Materials of High Thermal Stability: Design, Structure, and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor James Davis and his students of the Department of Chemistry at the University of South Alabama are exploring the synthesis, characterization, and properties of a new type of ionic liquid salts. The salts being investigated are expected are highly resistant to heat and retain their liquid character, without evaporation, decomposition, or flammability, for long periods of time. Salts of this type can be used as substitutes for more traditional liquids in applications ranging from heat transfer fluids and high-performance lubricants to biomass processing and the synthesis of important electronic materials such as semiconductors. The project brings together elements of chemical synthesis as well as material science and engineering, and offers engaged students a broad opportunity for gaining experience from a spectrum of activities. Since the institution at which the research is taking place serves a high proportion of individuals from groups underrepresented in the sciences and engineering, the project provides important opportunities to engage in the professional training of individuals from these communities.
 
Ionic liquid salts are materials of considerable fundamental interest and growing practical utility. Because of their non-volatility, ionic liquids can be used in applications requiring high temperatures, such as in heat transfer, lubrication, or high-temperature materials synthesis. Although typical ionic liquid salts have relatively high degrees of thermal stability, many of them are still incapable of being used for long durations at temperatures above 200 degrees Celsius.  By exploiting tetraarylphosphonium and triarylsulfonium salts, ionic liquid salts capable of remaining stable at temperatures of 300 degrees Celsius for periods over three months have been achieved by Professor Davis' group.  New strategies are being pursued to improve their thermal stability profile.  These strategies include the use of thermally stable anions, cross-linking of the molecules, the incorporation of graphene, and blending with oligophenylene ethers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our civilization is increasingly demanding technology that can perform faster and under more extreme conditions than ever.  However, doing so requires materials that can function at various extremes - pressure, speed, heat, and so on.  And, while many metals (titanium, for example) are suitable to function under many extremes of use, others - especially liquids - are not.  Why is it important for liquids to function under extremes - especially high temperatures?  Because we turn to them when lubrication is needed, or heat transfer (think coolant in an automobile radiator), or hydraulics (i.e. a car's brake system).  In order to accomplish these functions in devices intended to be used at ever higher temperatures, we need those liquids to be thermally stable.  Unfortunately, most modern lubricants, hydraulic fluids, and coolants are not especially stable at temperature extremes.  They chemically break down and are commonly subject to combustion at high temperatures if exposed to air.  Better materials are needed.

Our project has focussed on the design, synthesis, and study of advanced liquids capable of remaining stable at high temperatures - five hundred or more degrees Fahrenheit.  We have done so using an emerging class of materials known as "ionic liquids" as our starting point.  Ionic liquids, or ILs, are salts that are liquids at low temperatures; while table salt melts at around 1100F, ILs melt at temperatures as low or lower than the freezing point of water.  However, because of their ionic nature, these liquids cannot evaporate.  Unlike what would happen to a puddle of spilled water, a puddle of spilled IL would remain in place after a century - they just don't evaporate.  Our task then became to prepare ILs that not only melt at convenient temperatures, but which can also endure unusually high temperatures as well.  Working with a team of undergraduate students over the funding period of the grant, we succeeded in doing so.  In fact, our effort resulted in the creation of what we believe to be the most thermally stable organic (i.e. non-metallic) materials heretofore described.  These materials, ILs composed of phosphorous-based cations and fluorine-based anions, have (for example) already shown considerable promise as heat transfer fluids - such fluids being absolutely critical to enabling new solar energy technologies. Indeed, several of our salts have shown performance superior to currently available commercial fluids, including industry-leading DowTherm A, while lacking the potential for combustion which exists with the latter.  We are gratified to note that our new materials have garnered media attention from the wider chemical community. Articles about them have been published in leading trade media such as Chemical & Engineering News and Tribology and Lubrication Technology.  Furthermore, prelininary discussions have occured between our group and two commercial firms potentially interested in using them in commercial applications.

Not only has the project resulted in meaningful scientific advances, it has served as a valuable platform for education and training as well.  Over the course of the grant eight different undergraduate students gained valuable hands-on experience with doing the sort of real-world chemistry not commonly encountered in instructional laboratories.  Except for one, all of these individuals have gone on to undertake graduate studies in chemistry, and they (and others like them) will become the next generation of industrial chemists and chemical educators on which the chemical enterprise relies.  We note that more than 25% of the United States' gross domestic product (GDP) arises from the chemical industry!.  At the same time, our project provided a training opportunity for a postdoctoral researcher who is now emplyed as a research chemist with one of the country's leading producers of specialty isotope-enriched materials, critical substances in an array of technologies including diagnostic nuclear medicine.

Our group is profoundly grateful to the National Science Foundation - and the taxpayers which fund it - for having supported this project.  It is our hope and belief that the expenditure of funds for this project will pay dividends down the road.
